title:
HPPSC HPAS Paper 2 English - 
Grammar: Fill in the Blanks- Beginner level
instruction:
General Instructions


The test contain 10 questions.Each question has 4 options out of which only one is correct.You have to finish the test in 12 minutes.There is 0.66 negative marking in this test.

You will be awarded 2 mark for each correct answer.

There is no negative marking for the questions that you have not attempted.

You can write this test only once. Make sure that you complete the test before you submit the test and/or close the browser.

quiz.text:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

I met him ______ the university during my masters.
quiz.solution:
The correct preposition is at.

Key Points​

  • ​Let's look at the use of these three prepositions in the context of time and place:
  • Use 'in' to refer to a general, longer period of time, such as months, years, decades, or centuries such as:
    • in April, in 2015, or in the 21st century.
  • Use 'on' to talk about particular days, dates, and holidays such as:
    • on Monday, on Memorial day, on Diwali, etc.
  • ​For the most specific times or places, and for holidays without the word “day,” we use 'at' such as:
    • at midnight, at noon, at 7 pm, at home, at the office, etc.
  • As a specific location i.e. university is given, 'at' will be used in the blank part of the sentence.
     

​Correct Sentence: I met him at the university during my masters. 

 ​​​​Additional Information  ​

  • There are certain phrases/nouns which are not preceded by a preposition (especially 'on').
  • Some of them are given below:
    • today, tomorrow, yesterday, the next day/month/year, tonight, last night, etc.
  • For example:​
    • I met her on last Saturday. 
    • I met her last Saturday.

quiz.text:
Choose the correct answer for the blank from the given options. 

India is one of _______ biggest countries in the world.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'the'. 

Key Points

  • The definite article 'the' is used before singular and plural nouns when the noun is specific or particular/ known to the reader.​
  • Superlative adjectives (biggest, largest, thinnest, smartest, etc.) are preceded by the definite article 'the' before them. 
  • Examples, 
    • Researchers have just completed the largest-ever survey.
    • Quitting that job was the smartest move I ever made.
  • From the given explanation and examples, we can understand that 'the' should be used in the given blank. 
  • Therefore, option 1 is the correct answer. 


  • 'One of the' is a phrase which is always followed by a plural noun and a singular verb. 
    • For example, One of the students has given the correct answer.

 

Hinglish

  • The definite article 'the' का प्रयोग singular and plural nouns से पहले किया जाता है जब noun विशिष्ट या विशेष / पाठक को ज्ञात होती है।
  • Superlative adjectives (biggest, largest, thinnest, smartest, etc.) उनके पहले definite article 'the' होता है।
  • Examples, 
    • Researchers have just completed the largest-ever survey.
    • Quitting that job was the smartest move I ever made.
  • दिए गए स्पष्टीकरण और उदाहरणों से, हम समझ सकते हैं कि दिए गए blank स्थान में 'the' का प्रयोग किया जाना चाहिए।
  • अतः option 1 सही उत्तर है।

quiz.text:
Directions: Fill in the blank with the most appropriate option.

She _____ your help.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'needs.'

Key Points

  • In the given sentence, the pronoun 'She' is a third-person singular pronoun.
  • We know that a third-person singular pronoun always takes a third-person present singular verb.
  • We use 'do' with other personal pronouns (you, we, they) and with plural noun forms.
  • The verb 'need' is the base form of the verb.
  • Therefore, from the given options the only third-person present singular verb 'needs' should be used in the blank.
     

Hence, the correct answer is option 4.

Complete Sentence: She needs your help.

quiz.text:
Direction: Choose the most appropriate answer and fill in the blanks:

My teacher says reading is very important, and I agree ______ her.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'with'.

Key Points

  • We use 'agree with' with a person if we have the same opinion as that person.
    • Example: I don’t agree with my relatives when it comes to politics.
  • We use 'agree on' to share the same opinion about items, topics, plans, or standards.
    • Example: All parties agreed on plans to expand the Rideau Centre.​
  • We use 'agree to' to commit to (a course of action, a proposal, etc.).
    • We agree to do an action – so agree to is followed by a verb – and this means you promise to do the action.
      • Example: The manager agreed to the recommendation submitted by the working group.​
  • Hence, the preposition 'with' should be used to make the sentence grammatically correct.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 'with'.
     

​Correct sentence: My teacher says reading is very important, and I agree with her.

Additional Information

  • The meaning of 'agree' is to have the same opinion about something; concur.
    • ​Example: I completely agree with your recent editorial.

quiz.text:
Choose the correct word/phrase that best completes the sentence.

No one wants to have extra work tonight, ________?
quiz.solution:
The correct phrase to complete the sentence is 'do they'.

Key Points

  • Question tags turn a statement into a question. They are often used for checking information that we think we know is true. Usually, if the main clause is positive, the question tag is negative, and if the main clause is negative, the question tag is positive.
  • Examples:
    • It's cold (positive), isn't it (negative)?
    • It isn't cold (negative), is it (positive)?
  • ​In the given sentence, the main clause is negative and is in the simple present tense. Therefore, we need a positive question tag and 'do' should be used to speak about the present.
  • "Each, everyone, nobody, none, etc." are singular hence they take singular verb/ singular pronoun/ singular adjective with them. But their question tag will take plural verb and plural pronoun.
  • Therefore, according to the explanation and examples, option 3 is the correct answer.
     

Complete Sentence: No one wants to have extra work tonight, do they?

quiz.text:
Direction: Choose the most appropriate answer and fill in the blanks:

We have ______ Delhi.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'reached'.

Key Points

  • The given sentence is in the Present Perfect Tense.
  • The structure for present perfect tense is:
    • Subject + has/have + V3 form of the verb + Object 
      • Example: We have progressed a lot.
  • The V3 for the verb 'reach' is 'reached'.​​
  • Therefore, the correct answer is 'reached'.
     

​Correct sentence: We have reached Delhi.

quiz.text:
Complete the following sentence:

He is addicted ________ drinking.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'to'.

Key Points

  • 'Addicted' in the given sentence is an adjective.
  • 'To' preposition is used after it.
  • 'To' preposition is used with adjectives when we talk about the behaviour and feelings.
  • For example:
    • Be kind to her.
    • I cannot bear people being cruel to animals.
  • Thus, the correct answer will be option 2.

Hence, the correct sentence is: He is addicted to drinking.

Additional Information
 

  • Let's look at the usage of the other given options:
  • Preposition 'against' is used is used in opposition to, contrary to, adverse or hostile to.
  • For example:
    • He is fighting against all odds to get his work completed.
  • Preposition 'with' is used to show the way in which somebody does something.
  • For example:
    • He behaved with great dignity.
  • Preposition 'at' is used with specific time of the day.
  • For example:
    • The meeting begins at three o' clock.

quiz.text:
Direction: Choose the most appropriate answer and fill in the blanks:

There is an alliance ______ the three European nations.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'between'.

Key Points

  • Usage of Between - We can use between for any number of elements, as long as all the elements are separate and distinct.
    • For Example - Negotiations between the member states collapsed last night.
  • Hence, the preposition 'between' should be used to make the sentence grammatically correct.
    • ​​Correct sentence: There is an alliance between the three European nations.

​ Additional Information

  • We use among to talk about things that are not clearly separated because they are part of a group or crowd or mass of objects.
    • Example: The ancient fountain was hidden among the trees.
  • When we use the passive voice, we can use a phrase with by to say who did the action.
    • Example: The new street was opened by the Mayor.
  • We use between to refer to two things that are clearly separated.
    • Example: Our holiday house is between the mountains and the sea.​
  • ​We use into to talk about the movement of something, usually with a verb that expresses movement (e.g.  go, come).
  • It shows where something is or was going.
    • Example: Helen came into the room.
  • Hence, the preposition 'between' should be used to make the sentence grammatically correct.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 'among.'
    • ​​Correct sentence: There is an alliance between the three European nations.

quiz.text:
Choose the correct form of adverb for the given sentence: 

This book is ______ interesting.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is 'very'.

Key Points

  • Very: We use "very" to show there is a higher degree of some quality. It often appears in sentences with a positive meaning, also it is used with present participle.
    • Ex: That is a very good movie, very daring.
  • Too: On the other hand, "too" means there is more of the quality than you want. This shows a negative idea.
    • Ex: That movie is too violent for me.
  • Much: "Much" is used with a comparative degree also with the past participle.
    • Ex: Much surprised, much needed.
  • Here in the sentence, as we know that the word interesting is act as a present participle so we need to use the adverb very before it.
  • Hence, option 1 is the correct answer.

The correct sentence is: This book is very interesting.

Additional Information

Difference between "very" and " too" 

  • The main difference between "very" and "too" is that using "too" suggests that there is some problem. On a really hard day, you might come home and say:
    • I am too tired to eat, so we should not go out for dinner.
  • On a better day, you might say:
    • I am very tired, but I can go out for dinner.

quiz.text:
Fill in the blank with the correct option.

I _______ speak both English and Chinese fluently.
quiz.solution:
The correct answer is can.

Key Points

  • A modal or a modal auxiliary is a word such as 'can' or 'would' which is used with the main verb (the 1st form of the verb) to express ideas such as possibility, intention, or necessity.
  • 'Can' expresses ability. 'Cannot' shows inability. Sometimes 'can' is used in the sense of 'may' to give permission.
  • Could is the past tense of can. It is used to talk about ability that existed in the past.
  • 'Must' expresses strong obligation and necessity.
  • Example:
    • He can play baseball very well. (ability)
    • Till last year I could read without glasses. (past ability)
    • May I use your phone? (permission)
    • The orders of the seniors must be followed. (obligation)
  • Since the given sentence talks about the subject's ability to speak two languages at present, the modal verb 'can' will be used in the blank part of the sentence.
     

Correct Sentence: I can speak both English and Chinese fluently. 

​Additional Information

  • If should is used after lest, it indicates a negative purpose.
  • Example:
    • Hurry up lest you should miss the bus.
